title: How to Make Gel Eyeliner

methods.name: Mixing Up Basic DIY Gel Eyeliner

steps.headline: Place a small amount of loose eyeshadow in a container.
steps.description: To mix up your own gel liner in a hurry, find a loose eyeshadow pigment in the shade that you want to line your eyes with. Sprinkle a small amount into the lid of its container or on another flat surface that you can mix on. It’s best not to use eyeshadow pigment with glitter. The particles may fall in your eyes if you make a liner with the glitter. If you don’t have a loose shadow pigment, you can scrape a pressed shadow with a nail file or butter knife to get some pigment to work with.

steps.headline: Add a small dab of petroleum jelly.
steps.description: When you’ve got the eyeshadow pigment in ready, use a toothpick to place a small amount of petroleum jelly in the container with it. Stir the shadow and petroleum jelly together to form a colored gel. Start with an extremely small amount of petroleum jelly, and only add more if necessary. There should be more pigment than jelly. Swipe a small bit of the gel liner onto your hand with the toothpick to test the color. If it’s not as dark or pigmented as you’d like, mix in more of the eyeshadow.

steps.headline: Apply the liner with a brush.
steps.description: Once you’re satisfied with the color of your gel liner, use an eyeliner brush to trace it along your lashline. Because the petroleum jelly is extremely emollient, it’s a good idea to set the gel liner with the powder eyeshadow in the same color. This gel liner isn’t particularly long-wearing and can smudge easily. It’s best used if you’re doing a grunge makeup look or a smoky eye where you won’t mind some smudging.

methods.name: Preparing Two Ingredient All-Natural Gel Eyeliner

steps.headline: Add the charcoal to a dish.
steps.description: An all-natural black gel eyeliner gets its color from activated charcoal, which is usually used to treat stomach issues and for other medicinal purposes. Open 1 to 2 activated charcoal capsules and dump the powder into a small bowl. You can usually find activated charcoal capsules at the drugstore. They’re also available at a variety of online stores.

steps.headline: Mix in the coconut oil.
steps.description: With the charcoal powder in the bowl, add ½ teaspoon (2.25 g) of coconut oil. Stir the two together with a toothpick or even an eyeliner brush until you have a smooth paste. You can substitute grapeseed or sweet almond oil for the coconut oil. Just add ¼ (1 ml) teaspoon instead. You can also mix distilled water with the charcoal instead of the coconut oil. However, a water-based liner won’t last as long on the eyes.

steps.headline: Transfer the liner to a container and use a brush to apply it.
steps.description: Once you’ve created the gel liner, use a spoon or small spatula to place it in a small pot or other container with a lid. When you’re ready to line your eyes, use your usual eyeliner brush and carefully drag the liner across your lash line. The gel liner will stain clothing and other fabrics, so be careful when you’re putting it in a storage container and applying it. Refrigerating the gel liner will help it last longer. Even if you store it in the fridge, you should throw it away after a month.

methods.name: Creating Longer Wearing All-Natural Gel Eyeliner

steps.headline: Melt the wax and oil together.
steps.description: Fill a small saucepan halfway with water, and place a glass bowl or measuring cup in the pan. Add ½ teaspoon (2.5 g) of grated beeswax and ½ teaspoon (2.25 g) of coconut oil to the glass bowl. Bring the water in the pan to a gentle boil over medium heat until the wax and oil melt, which should take 10 to 15 minutes. You can substitute grapeseed or sweet almond oil for the coconut oil if you prefer. You can usually purchase beeswax at your local farmers' market, health food store, or organic grocery store.

steps.headline: Mix in the charcoal.
steps.description: When the wax and oil are melted, remove the glass bowl from the double boiler. Add ¼ teaspoon (1.25 g) of activated charcoal powder to the bowl. Stir with a spoon until the charcoal is completely blended into the wax and oil.

steps.headline: Add the water.
steps.description: Once the charcoal is fully combined with the wax mixture, mix in ¼ teaspoon (1.25 ml) of distilled water. Whisk the mixture until the water is fully incorporated and a smooth gel forms. If you find that the ingredients are separating, mix in a capsule full of lecithin to help bind the eyeliner. You can find lecithin capsules with other supplements at the drugstore.

steps.headline: Transfer to a container and store in the refrigerator.
steps.description: When the gel liner is completely mixed, use a spoon to place it in a small container with a lid. Keep the liner in the refrigerator to help keep it fresh. Because there are no preservatives in the eye liner, you should throw it out after 3 to 4 weeks.

steps.headline: Brush on the liner.
steps.description: For the best application, dip a small, narrow eyeliner brush into the liner. Apply the liner in as thin or thick a line as you’d like at your lash line. To remove the liner, apply some coconut oil to your eyes with a cotton ball. Wipe your eyes gently until all of the liner is removed.

tyn: Paper plate, lid, or other flat mixing surface
A small container with a lid
text: Mixing Up Basic DIY Gel Eyeliner Place a small amount of loose eyeshadow in a container. To mix up your own gel liner in a hurry, find a loose eyeshadow pigment in the shade that you want to line your eyes with. Sprinkle a small amount into the lid of its container or on another flat surface that you can mix on. It’s best not to use eyeshadow pigment with glitter. The particles may fall in your eyes if you make a liner with the glitter. If you don’t have a loose shadow pigment, you can scrape a pressed shadow with a nail file or butter knife to get some pigment to work with. Add a small dab of petroleum jelly. When you’ve got the eyeshadow pigment in ready, use a toothpick to place a small amount of petroleum jelly in the container with it. Stir the shadow and petroleum jelly together to form a colored gel. Start with an extremely small amount of petroleum jelly, and only add more if necessary. There should be more pigment than jelly. Swipe a small bit of the gel liner onto your hand with the toothpick to test the color. If it’s not as dark or pigmented as you’d like, mix in more of the eyeshadow. Apply the liner with a brush. Once you’re satisfied with the color of your gel liner, use an eyeliner brush to trace it along your lashline. Because the petroleum jelly is extremely emollient, it’s a good idea to set the gel liner with the powder eyeshadow in the same color. This gel liner isn’t particularly long-wearing and can smudge easily. It’s best used if you’re doing a grunge makeup look or a smoky eye where you won’t mind some smudging. Preparing Two Ingredient All-Natural Gel Eyeliner Add the charcoal to a dish. An all-natural black gel eyeliner gets its color from activated charcoal, which is usually used to treat stomach issues and for other medicinal purposes. Open 1 to 2 activated charcoal capsules and dump the powder into a small bowl. You can usually find activated charcoal capsules at the drugstore. They’re also available at a variety of online stores. Mix in the coconut oil. With the charcoal powder in the bowl, add ½ teaspoon (2.25 g) of coconut oil. Stir the two together with a toothpick or even an eyeliner brush until you have a smooth paste. You can substitute grapeseed or sweet almond oil for the coconut oil. Just add ¼ (1 ml) teaspoon instead. You can also mix distilled water with the charcoal instead of the coconut oil. However, a water-based liner won’t last as long on the eyes. Transfer the liner to a container and use a brush to apply it. Once you’ve created the gel liner, use a spoon or small spatula to place it in a small pot or other container with a lid. When you’re ready to line your eyes, use your usual eyeliner brush and carefully drag the liner across your lash line. The gel liner will stain clothing and other fabrics, so be careful when you’re putting it in a storage container and applying it. Refrigerating the gel liner will help it last longer. Even if you store it in the fridge, you should throw it away after a month. Creating Longer Wearing All-Natural Gel Eyeliner Melt the wax and oil together. Fill a small saucepan halfway with water, and place a glass bowl or measuring cup in the pan. Add ½ teaspoon (2.5 g) of grated beeswax and ½ teaspoon (2.25 g) of coconut oil to the glass bowl. Bring the water in the pan to a gentle boil over medium heat until the wax and oil melt, which should take 10 to 15 minutes. You can substitute grapeseed or sweet almond oil for the coconut oil if you prefer. You can usually purchase beeswax at your local farmers' market, health food store, or organic grocery store. Mix in the charcoal. When the wax and oil are melted, remove the glass bowl from the double boiler. Add ¼ teaspoon (1.25 g) of activated charcoal powder to the bowl. Stir with a spoon until the charcoal is completely blended into the wax and oil. Add the water. Once the charcoal is fully combined with the wax mixture, mix in ¼ teaspoon (1.25 ml) of distilled water. Whisk the mixture until the water is fully incorporated and a smooth gel forms. If you find that the ingredients are separating, mix in a capsule full of lecithin to help bind the eyeliner. You can find lecithin capsules with other supplements at the drugstore. Transfer to a container and store in the refrigerator. When the gel liner is completely mixed, use a spoon to place it in a small container with a lid. Keep the liner in the refrigerator to help keep it fresh. Because there are no preservatives in the eye liner, you should throw it out after 3 to 4 weeks. Brush on the liner. For the best application, dip a small, narrow eyeliner brush into the liner. Apply the liner in as thin or thick a line as you’d like at your lash line. To remove the liner, apply some coconut oil to your eyes with a cotton ball. Wipe your eyes gently until all of the liner is removed.

To mix up your own gel liner in a hurry, find a loose eyeshadow pigment in the shade that you want to line your eyes with.
Sprinkle a small amount into the lid of its container or on another flat surface that you can mix on.
It’s best not to use eyeshadow pigment with glitter.
The particles may fall in your eyes if you make a liner with the glitter.
If you don’t have a loose shadow pigment, you can scrape a pressed shadow with a nail file or butter knife to get some pigment to work with.
Add a small dab of petroleum jelly.
When you’ve got the eyeshadow pigment in ready, use a toothpick to place a small amount of petroleum jelly in the container with it.
Stir the shadow and petroleum jelly together to form a colored gel.
Start with an extremely small amount of petroleum jelly, and only add more if necessary.
There should be more pigment than jelly.
Swipe a small bit of the gel liner onto your hand with the toothpick to test the color.
If it’s not as dark or pigmented as you’d like, mix in more of the eyeshadow.
Apply the liner with a brush.
Once you’re satisfied with the color of your gel liner, use an eyeliner brush to trace it along your lashline.
Because the petroleum jelly is extremely emollient, it’s a good idea to set the gel liner with the powder eyeshadow in the same color.
This gel liner isn’t particularly long-wearing and can smudge easily.
It’s best used if you’re doing a grunge makeup look or a smoky eye where you won’t mind some smudging.
Preparing Two Ingredient All-Natural Gel Eyeliner Add the charcoal to a dish.
An all-natural black gel eyeliner gets its color from activated charcoal, which is usually used to treat stomach issues and for other medicinal purposes.
Open 1 to 2 activated charcoal capsules and dump the powder into a small bowl.
You can usually find activated charcoal capsules at the drugstore.
They’re also available at a variety of online stores.
Mix in the coconut oil.
With the charcoal powder in the bowl, add ½ teaspoon (2.25 g) of coconut oil.
Stir the two together with a toothpick or even an eyeliner brush until you have a smooth paste.
You can substitute grapeseed or sweet almond oil for the coconut oil.
Just add ¼ (1 ml) teaspoon instead.
You can also mix distilled water with the charcoal instead of the coconut oil.
However, a water-based liner won’t last as long on the eyes.
Transfer the liner to a container and use a brush to apply it.
Once you’ve created the gel liner, use a spoon or small spatula to place it in a small pot or other container with a lid.
When you’re ready to line your eyes, use your usual eyeliner brush and carefully drag the liner across your lash line.
The gel liner will stain clothing and other fabrics, so be careful when you’re putting it in a storage container and applying it.
Refrigerating the gel liner will help it last longer.
Even if you store it in the fridge, you should throw it away after a month.
Creating Longer Wearing All-Natural Gel Eyeliner Melt the wax and oil together.
Fill a small saucepan halfway with water, and place a glass bowl or measuring cup in the pan.
Add ½ teaspoon (2.5 g) of grated beeswax and ½ teaspoon (2.25 g) of coconut oil to the glass bowl.
Bring the water in the pan to a gentle boil over medium heat until the wax and oil melt, which should take 10 to 15 minutes.
You can substitute grapeseed or sweet almond oil for the coconut oil if you prefer.
You can usually purchase beeswax at your local farmers' market, health food store, or organic grocery store.
Mix in the charcoal.
When the wax and oil are melted, remove the glass bowl from the double boiler.
Add ¼ teaspoon (1.25 g) of activated charcoal powder to the bowl.
Stir with a spoon until the charcoal is completely blended into the wax and oil.
Add the water.
Once the charcoal is fully combined with the wax mixture, mix in ¼ teaspoon (1.25 ml) of distilled water.
Whisk the mixture until the water is fully incorporated and a smooth gel forms.
If you find that the ingredients are separating, mix in a capsule full of lecithin to help bind the eyeliner.
You can find lecithin capsules with other supplements at the drugstore.
Transfer to a container and store in the refrigerator.
When the gel liner is completely mixed, use a spoon to place it in a small container with a lid.
Keep the liner in the refrigerator to help keep it fresh.
Because there are no preservatives in the eye liner, you should throw it out after 3 to 4 weeks.
Brush on the liner.
For the best application, dip a small, narrow eyeliner brush into the liner.
Apply the liner in as thin or thick a line as you’d like at your lash line.
To remove the liner, apply some coconut oil to your eyes with a cotton ball.
Wipe your eyes gently until all of the liner is removed.
